By Emily Stephenson
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump will propose allowing parents to deduct spending on childcare from their income taxes in a speech on Monday meant to challenge the economic policies of Democratic rival Hillary Clinton
column2: a campaign aide said.The aide
column3: who asked not to be identified
column4: said on Sunday in outlining the plan: ""We don't want it to be an economic disadvantage to have children."" The aide said the campaign would have a more detailed childcare plan in the future.A wealthy businessman seeking his first public office
column5: Trump seeks to counter Clinton's argument he is out of touch with the problems of working families. He will also say that
column6: unlike Clinton
column7: his business policies would encourage companies to remain in the United States
column8: a concern of blue-collar workers he has tried to court
column10: to business leaders of the Detroit Economic Club
column11: Trump will also propose stronger protections for American intellectual property and a temporary moratorium on new regulations
column12: the aide said.Seeking to move beyond a week of discord
column13: Trump will outline  plans for trade
column15: regulation and energy policy. His plans include proposing a 15 percent corporate tax rate
column16: an idea that is on his website. The current federal rate is 35 percent.

column1: Senior aides and supporters said in television appearances on Sunday that Trump wanted to put behind him his disputes of last week with Republican Party leaders and the parents of a Muslim American soldier killed in Iraq.With the economy a major issue
column2: Clinton on Thursday lays out a plan of her own for the ""biggest investment in good-paying jobs since World War Two
column3: her campaign said.A Democrat like President Barack Obama
column4: Clinton will be buoyed by figures released on Friday showing U.S. employment rose more than expected for a second month in a row in July and wages picked up
column5: bolstering expectations of faster economic growth.

column1: Clinton has pledged that no family should pay more than 10 percent of its income on childcare. She has called for a tax cut to help middle-class parents cope with rising childcare costs and an expansion of a federally funded program that provides education and health services to low-income families with young children.In a phone call lasting little more than an hour on Sunday and run by some of Trump's most senior aides
column2: members of his newly announced economic advisory group shared their views on policy
column3: said banker Stephen Calk
column4: one of the members who took part.

column1: The Clinton campaign has criticized Trump over the advisory group
column2: announced on Friday
column3: for including no women and relying on members who come from hedge funds and investment banking
column4: a make-up at odds somewhat with Trump's populist message.Calk
column5: chief executive of Federal Savings Bank and National Bancorp Holdings

column7: recognizable"" names on the call who would be announced soon as joining the team but did not elaborate.A new Washington Post-ABC News opinion poll on Sunday showed Trump trailing Clinton by 8 percentage points after her party's convention in Philadelphia. A Reuters/Ipsos poll out on Friday showed the race closer three months ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential election. (Reporting by Emily Stephenson; Additional reporting by Mike Stone in New York; Editing by Howard Goller)"	['Clinton'

column1: By Jon Herskovitz
Helen Delich Bentley
column2: a former journalist and a U.S. Republican congresswoman from Maryland who gained global attention by smashing Japanese goods to protest Tokyo's trade policies
column3: died over the weekend at the age of 92
column4: officials said.Bentley upset a longtime Democratic congressman to win a U.S. House of Representatives seat in 1984
column5: a year in which Ronald Reagan's landslide victory in the presidential race helped bring several new faces from the party to Congress.The five-term congresswoman was a staunch advocate for the port of Baltimore and the state's maritime industry.

column1: After reports that Japanese company Toshiba had sold technology to the Soviet Union to help their submarines sail more quietly
column2: she led other members of Congress who used a sledgehammer to smash Japanese-made goods on the Capitol steps. The event came as tensions were running high with Tokyo over a widening U.S. trade deficit with the country. She left Congress to run for governor of Maryland but lost in the party's primary.

column1: Congresswoman Bentley worked with tenacity
column2: energy
column3: and passion on behalf of her constituents
column4: making her a rare breed in politics and a role model to public servants across Maryland
column5: current Maryland Governor Larry Hogan
column6: a Republican
column7: wrote in a Facebook post.Bentley was born in 1923 in Nevada and her parents were immigrants from Yugoslavia. After earning a bachelor's degree in journalism
column8: she found a job with the Baltimore Sun
column9: beginning a three-decade long relationship with the newspaper in which she wrote ground-breaking stories on the maritime industry and labor

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN10I026	Trump ends difficult week by focusing on Hillary Clinton	"
By Steve Holland
| WINDHAM
column2: N.H.

column1: WINDHAM
column2: N.H. Republican Donald Trump on Saturday ended a tough week for his campaign in the state that launched him toward the presidential nomination and he did what Republicans have been urging him to do: Keep the focus on Democrat Hillary Clinton.""Her greatest achievement is getting out of trouble
column3: Trump told supporters.Trump's victory in the Feb. 10 Republican primary in New Hampshire put him in position to win the party's nomination
column4: but he trails Clinton in the state by 15 points in the latest WBUR/MassINC poll
column5: 47 percent to 32 percent.Trump came to New Hampshire after a troubled week in which he tangled with fellow Republican leaders and sparred verbally with the parents of a Muslim soldier who died fighting for the United States in Iraq in 2004.Clinton
column6: getting a lift from the Democratic National Convention
column7: took advantage of Trump's stumbles to surge into the lead in national polls and in many battleground states.

column1: Now Trump has begun heeding the advice of Republican officials who say he needs to take the fight to Clinton to give the party a chance to win the White House on Nov. 8.Trump seized on Clinton's comments Friday that she had ""short-circuited"" when she said a week ago that FBI Director James Comey had said she had been truthful to the American people in her use of a private email server while U.S. secretary of state from 2009 to 2013.
In fact
column2: Comey had concluded that Clinton was ""extremely careless"" with classified emails. He directly contradicted many of the statements Clinton had made about her use of the server.Trump spent the lion's share of a campaign speech in a crowded high school gymnasium to go after Clinton on the subject in trying to raise questions about her trustworthiness.""I think the people of this country don't want somebody who is going to short circuit
column3: Trump said.

column1: Trump also sought to turn the tables on Clinton
column2: who has consistently accused the New York developer of being temperamentally unfit to be president.""She is a totally unhinged person
column3: Trump said. (Reporting by Steve Holland; Editing by James Dalgleish)"	['Clinton'

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-pence-idUSKCN10G12L	On the trail with Mike Pence: Putting out fires lit by Trump	"
By Doina Chiacu and Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON If Mike Pence had any doubts about what life would be like on the 2016 Republican presidential ticket with Donald Trump
column2: the past week will have erased them: He is the damage control guy.The Indiana governor who swore off political mudslinging years ago heard Trump call Democratic rival Hillary Clinton ""the devil"" and watched him fan the flames of a feud with the parents of a Muslim soldier who died saving U.S. troops in Iraq.Unlike many vice presidential running mates
column3: the mild-mannered Pence was not tapped as the attack dog in the Nov. 8  presidential election. Trump has that part down pat.Pence's job is harder: softening Trump's rough edges and limiting the fallout from what many Republicans see as the nominee's self-inflicted wounds.A week ago
column4: for example
column5: Pence rowed back on Trump's blacklist of some media outlets
column6: saying the campaign is discussing changing course.Last Sunday
column7: as Trump's dispute with the parents of slain U.S. Army Captain Humayun Khan boiled over
column8: Pence issued a statement praising the soldier as an ""American hero"" and saying that his family ""should be cherished by every American.""    On Wednesday
column9: Pence offered his own endorsement to House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan
column11: after Trump infuriated many party leaders by declining to endorse Ryan in his re-election bid.Pence
column12: who swore off negative campaigning after losing a vituperative congressional race in 1990
column15: delights in using monikers such as ""Crooked Hillary"" and ""the devil"" to describe Clinton.Trump has made clear he values Pence
column16: telling a rally on Thursday in Portland
column18: that he and his running mate have a ""great relationship.""

column1: But Pence must walk a fine line.Even as he defuses Trump's verbal bombs
column2: Pence must be careful to show he knows who is boss. He also has to stick to his own principles while not appearing to be trying to undermine the man who chose him as his No. 2.Should Trump win
column3: Pence
column4: a former congressman
column5: could serve as a conduit to the U.S. Congress. But if Trump loses
column6: Pence could emerge as a possible White House contender for 2020.Republican strategist Charlie Black said Pence has shown some political deftness.""He should have expected he would do some of this and provide more of the even-tempered
column7: articulate
column8: measured responses

column1: But Republican strategist Ryan Williams said Pence is in an ""impossible spot"" and said that Trump's missteps could cast a shadow over his running mate's political future.    ""Mike Pence is a good Republican but unfortunately he will be associated with the controversies that have ensnared the Trump-Pence ticket and will be tied to whatever the consequences of this election are
column2: Williams said.POSITIVE PENCE
column3: TESTY TRUMP

column1: Trump's off-the-cuff insults and controversial proposals
column2: such as a temporary ban on Muslims entering the United States and a plan to build a wall along the Mexican border to keep illegal immigrants out
column3: have made many in the party establishment uneasy.The Republican nominee's feud with the Khan family made for an awkward moment for Pence at a campaign event in Carson City
column4: Nevada. A military mother asked Pence how could he tolerate Trump's disrespect for the armed forces
column5: which prompted boos.Pence admonished the crowd to tone it down. ""Folks
column6: that's what freedom looks like and that's what freedom sounds like
column7: he said before calling Humayun Khan an American hero.Pence was asked on Thursday by an 11-year-old boy at a North Carolina rally if his role was ""softening up"" Trump's policies and words.Pence replied that he and Trump were ""shoulder to shoulder"" in the campaign.Christopher Devine
column8: co-author of the book ""The VP Advantage"" and an assistant political science professor at the University of Dayton in Ohio
column9: said that if Trump loses the November election
column10: Pence may try to position himself as a conservative bridge between Trump supporters and traditional Republicans. That may be an added reason for Pence's cautious approach.""He has to be very careful about how he handles the defense of Donald Trump
column11: Devine said. (Editing by Caren Bohan and Leslie Adler)"	['Carson'

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-counterterrorism-drones-idUSKCN10H0KP	Obama administration releases redacted version of drone policy	"
WASHINGTON The Obama administration released a redacted version of President Barack Obama's once-secret policy on drone strikes abroad following a freedom of information lawsuit filed last year
column2: the American Civil Liberties Union said on Saturday.The release of the 18-page Presidential Policy Guidance document
column3: as well as other Department of Defense papers
column4: follows an order by a U.S. District Court judge in February requiring the Justice Department to disclose the document
column5: also known as ""the Playbook.""It sets out the law and rules the government must follow when carrying out targeted killings and the capture of terrorist suspects abroad. Obama pledged in 2013 to provide greater transparency about counter-terrorism operations
column6: including drone strikes overseas
column7: amid calls by some U.S. lawmakers and rights groups for more openness.  ACLU's deputy legal director
column8: Jameel Jaffer
column9: welcomed the release of the documents
column10: saying they provide new details about policy standards and insights into the process for targeting individuals with lethal force or for capture.""Its release now will inform an ongoing debate about the lawfulness and wisdom of the government's counter-terrorism policies

column1: The ACLU's lawsuit sought information
column2: among other things
column3: on the law and policies used to justify lethal force and how the government picks targets.According to the documents
column4: published by the ACLU
column5: strikes against high-value terrorist targets can be taken ""when there is near certainty"" that the person is present
column6: and that no civilians will be injured or killed
column7: and is necessary to ""achieve U.S. policy objectives"".

column1: The administration has defended its use of drones as essential in fighting al Qaeda and other militants in countries such as Pakistan
column2: Afghanistan and Yemen. Some drone strikes have killed civilians who were not targets
column3: igniting local anger.""The president has emphasized that the U.S. Government should be as transparent as possible with the American people about our counter-terrorism operations
column4: the manner in which they are conducted
column5: and their results
column6: National Security Council spokesman Ned Price said of Saturday's release of documents.""Our counter-terrorism actions are effective and legal
column7: and their legitimacy is best demonstrated by making public more information about these actions as well as setting clear standards for other nations to follow
column8: he added.

column1: Naureen Shah
column2: Amnesty International's U.S. director for security and human rights
column3: also welcomed the documents but said more was needed to ensure the policy was followed.""The Obama administration's disclosures are welcome but they only tell part of the story and obscure disturbing practices. We still know extremely little about the standards that would govern signature strikes and so-called rescuer strikes
column4: which have involved potentially unlawful killings
column5: Shah added. (Reporting by Lesley Wroughton; Editing by Leslie Adler and Paul Simao)"	['Paul'

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-advisers-factbox-idUSKCN10G1S7	Factbox: Republican presidential candidate Trump's economic team	"
U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump on Friday announced his team of economic advisers
column2: among whom are a hedge fund manager
column3: a former top steel executive and a former high-ranking U.S. government official. Trump said he would deliver a speech on his economic policy plan on Monday.Here are some facts on the members of his economic team:JOHN PAULSON
column4: HEDGE FUND MANAGER

column1: Paulson is best known on Wall Street for his bet against the overheated housing market in 2007 that netted him and his investors billions of dollars in profits. But Paulson's calls on stocks and the economy have been less accurate lately. His investments have lost some $15 billion in assets in the last five years
column2: leaving his Paulson & Co Inc hedge fund with roughly $13 billion at the end of June. He is known for making contrarian bets and being patient. He has been one of only a handful of hedge fund managers to have publicly endorsed Trump. Many others have said privately that they are still on the fence or leaning toward his Democratic rival
column3: Hillary Clinton.STEVE FEINBERG
column4: PRIVATE EQUITY FUND MANAGER

column1: Feinberg is chief executive officer of Cerberus Capital Management LP
column2: a private equity firm he co-founded in 1992. He headed the investment firm during its failed takeover of automaker Chrysler in 2007. The investment firm served as Chrysler's majority owner until the troubled car maker was restructured in a government-sponsored bankruptcy in 2009.Feinberg had promised to revive the company
column3: according to a New York Times profile
column4: but instead lost billions. (here) Feinberg has defended his role to try to save the carmaker. He ultimately had to appeal to Washington for help.     DAVID MALPASS
column5: FORMER TREASURY
column6: STATE DEPARTMENT OFFICIAL

column1: Malpass served under two previous Republican administrations
column2: first as a deputy assistant Treasury secretary for President Ronald Reagan and later as a deputy assistant secretary of State for President George H.W. Bush.        Malpass

column5: trade reform
column6: regulatory reform and energy reform
column7: although he gave few specifics. ""We need more effective spending and Trump wants to do that - to have stronger finances for the country
column8: he said.Malpass has been a vocal critic of the U.S. Federal Reserve's monetary policy since the financial crisis
column9: in particular its large bond holdings.Malpass
column10: who was also previously chief economist at investment bank Bear Stearns
column12: an investment consulting firm. PETER NAVARRO

column1: Navarro is the only adviser on the list with a doctorate in economics and the only one who has spent most of his life as an academic. He earned his doctorate at Harvard University and is now a professor of economics and public policy at the University of California
column2: Irvine's business school.Navarro has written nine books
column3: three of them critical about China's effect on the rest of the world
column4: including ""Death by China: Confronting the Dragon - A Global Call to Action."" He thinks the United States should be tougher on trade and intellectual property theft and has proposed slapping a 45 percent tariff on Chinese imports.

column1: Navarro recently wrote in an opinion piece in the Los Angeles Times that Trump would crack down on any country ""that cheats on its trade deals using practices such as currency manipulation and illegal export subsidies."" (here)HOWARD LORBER
column2: HOLDING COMPANY CEO

column1: Lorber is president and CEO of holding company Vector Group Ltd (VGR.N)

column3: who had a long history of political donations to Democrats

column5: as his finance chair in May.

column4: DiMicco wrote in a July 10 blog post on his website

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-economy-idUSKCN10G2IO	Trump's economic advisory group clashes with populist image	"
By James Oliphant
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's team of economic policy advisers is packed with moguls from the hedge fund and investment banking industries that he has railed against in the past.And none of them are women - a demographic group he needs to court if he hopes to win in November.Trump's campaign has been powered by a populist message that criticizes corporate America for outsourcing jobs
column2: profiting at the expense of everyday workers and buying influence in Washington. The message resonates best with middle-class and working-class voters buffeted by the forces of globalization. But among the members of the 13-member team of advisers announced on Friday are hedge-fund billionaire John Paulson and investment bankers Steve Feinberg and Andy Beal
column3: as well as a former top steel executive and a former high-ranking U.S. government official. ""It is a hallowed campaign tradition. Malign an industry
column4: but court its wealthy big shots
column5: said Erik Gordon
column6: a professor of law and business at the University of Michigan.The reliance on Wall Street executives comes after Trump spent much of his primary campaign lambasting the industry for paying too little in taxes. ""The hedge fund guys are getting away with murder
column7: Trump said in an interview last year.One of the best known of Trump's panel is Paulson

column1: Whether Trump will heed the counsel of his conservative-leaning economic advisers or steer his own course was also raised by Lanhee Chen

column1: But the panel fits with the themes of Trump's campaign in another way. Trump often has boasted about bringing in successful business people to tackle Washington's entrenched problems
column2: and many of Trump's supporters see his background in business as among his biggest assets.GUY WITH A BINDER

column1: Some critics seized upon the lack of women on Trump's panel. After being asked this week to identify women he might appoint to his cabinet if elected
column2: Trump could only respond with the name of his daughter Ivanka.

column6: though.)"" Clinton's campaign wrote. The campaign declined to comment on Trump's advisers.Trump has struggled with women voters since his campaign began. Some 65 percent of women have an unfavorable view of Trump
